user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count:
```c
int
mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count (void)
{
  int res;

#if defined(__linux__) || defined(__GLIBC__)
  /* On Linux kernel try first 'sched_getaffinity()' as it should be
     the native API.
     Also try it first on other kernels if Glibc is used. */
  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;

  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_cpuset_getaffinity_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;
#else  /* ! __linux__ && ! __GLIBC__ */
  /* On non-Linux kernels 'cpuset_getaffinity()' could be the native API,
     while 'sched_getaffinity()' could be implemented in compatibility layer. */
  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_cpuset_getaffinity_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;

  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;
#endif /* ! __linux__ && ! __GLIBC__ */

  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_np_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;

  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_w32_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;

  return -1;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No controlling expressions in this function are manifestly invariant. The only C controlling constructs are several if (0 < res) tests; in each case res is assigned immediately beforehand by a function call, so the controlling expression depends on the function result and is not a compile-time constant or invariant. There are no loops (for/while/do-while) whose controlling expressions are constant, and no do-while with an essentially Boolean constant controlling expression. Preprocessor conditionals (#if defined(...)) are not C controlling expressions governed by MISRA C Rule 14.3. Therefore there are no fragments in this function that need further investigation for Rule 14.3.
